text: let's talk about a simple pre-trade checklist that I'm going to share with you all the goal of this video is to give you the framework for a checklist that is indepth enough to make sure that we're not making stupid errors but not so in depth that it won't be used I found that to be a big problem for me when I first started trading is I would have all these great ideas on what I wanted to look at and what I thought was important but then I'd run into the issue of it became so burdensome that I wouldn't use it so if something although might be super detailed and have everything that you could possibly need in it it's completely useless if it's not usable so this video is designed to strike a happy medium I encourage you to add or remove things as you find suits your needs the main thing I think about with pre-trade post-trade checklists is that in the beginning it should be a very manual process where we follow each step but then over time as you develop the skill set and the habits you don't really have to have an actual checklist that you are tick boox and filling out in that manner I don't do that anymore myself but I generally follow this process so what's up everybody welcome back to all the outliers and a shout out to the patreon family you guys make content like this

text: is essentially 3 cents very small and if you don't know what good liquidity looks like there's a few things to keep an eyeball for obviously the bidas spread the number of shares that trade in a given day open interest is another good indication whether or not it has weeklys because they won't offer weeklys unless there's demand for those expiration Cycles stuff like that and you have to figure out what makes sense for you the one thing I can make sure is important to share with you not really sure if I can make sure makes sense but one thing I can say unequivocally is that if something is not going through a volatile period this is as good as it gets and if volatility starts to spike markets widen considerably so if you're looking at something that's not going through a super vol period and you're like man this is kind of a liquid it gets insanely worse if volatility kicks up so you should be aware of that when you're thinking about liquidity now the next few things don't necessarily tell us whether or not the trade goes on or not but it informs our decision and our thoughts about the trade the first one is does the individual product have any upcoming announcements does it have earnings coming up and those are important details for example if you're like oh man I really want to put a to trade on in FedEx for whatever

text: decision and our thoughts about the trade the first one is does the individual product have any upcoming announcements does it have earnings coming up and those are important details for example if you're like oh man I really want to put a to trade on in FedEx for whatever reason I love it here and you're not aware that it has earnings coming up you are stepping in front of pretty significant risk and you're none the wiser so when you're trading individual stocks looking for earnings is important notice how on the last earning cycle here it had this big gap you should be aware if something has earnings coming up the main time I see this hurting Traders is when they're looking for volatility you're looking for your running scans that are looking for things with high implied volatility and a lot of times that's going to be around an earnings event or an announcement of some sort maybe it's a biotech stock and you don't connect those dots and then all of a sudden now you're putting a trade on that's going to take you through a binary event that's kind of a problem the next thing is are there any broad Market events this will impact trades differently but you should be aware of what's coming up on the week ahead a great tool to use for this I really like them is called Financial juice and I am an affiliate for them there's a

text: fomc statements right now in the current market environment they're massive have huge impacts on things however in 2016 the fomc rate statement didn't really have a whole lot going on it didn't impact the markets that much so you do have to be in tune with what's relevant at a given point in time and what the market cares about now the last thing here before we get into the rest of the checklist is what does my portfolio need now when we're scanning for trades I always have a big process that's driven by this and this belongs in your pre- trade checklist as well and the primary reason is this if you find the greatest trade that you've ever found but your portfolio doesn't need that risk it doesn't go on that's all there is to it so it's important to make sure that we're always keeping this portfolio Concept in mind when we're looking at these different trades Okay cool so the next step here is kind of hypothesis generation and confirmation for me at this stage I already know what the trade is that I'm thinking about putting On Loosely I haven't gone through the details of structuring it but a couple things I want to make sure I'm considering the first one is is this some sort of opportunistic trade or am I looking for specific exposure and to make sure that this trade fits this question and still fits within the BR portfolio

text: details of structuring it but a couple things I want to make sure I'm considering the first one is is this some sort of opportunistic trade or am I looking for specific exposure and to make sure that this trade fits this question and still fits within the BR portfolio this matters because the way that I size things the way I scan for correlation for things is really based on this The Next Step here in hypothesis generation is what is your hypothesis blanket and how does the trade work this is important because some Traders have a hard time getting specific with this kind of stuff and what I'm talking about is going back to this example maybe you want to trade FedEx for some reason and you think it's going to go up your hypothesis then would be I am bullish in FedEx I think it's going to go up potentially X number of points over the next X time frame those details are important specifically when you're trading options because every single option trade you put on is time bound so you have to get comfortable integrating a time element to your hypothesis and this leads down to the next point which is what is the breadth of analysis and does that line up with your hypothesis so when you start going through this trade again for example FedEx we think it's to go up as I start overlaying my technical analysis okay I have a

text: down to the next point which is what is the breadth of analysis and does that line up with your hypothesis so when you start going through this trade again for example FedEx we think it's to go up as I start overlaying my technical analysis okay I have a ascending 9-day moving average the gap between the 9 the 50 and the 200 are widening they're all positively sloping it's near a plus two linear aggression Channel which I wouldn't love yada y y the whole point here is you might look at something and make a judgment call but it's super important to go much further into detail to see and make sure that the Confluence of evidence that you're looking up marries up beautifully with what whatever your hypothesis is and sometimes you might find out that what you originally thought actually doesn't look that great and if you need some ideas on how I go about technical analysis you could check out this video here and if you couldn't tell this beautiful handwriting is actually from a free download which I'll also throw that in the notes below for you to check out to get this exact pre-trade checklist if you don't know I have to say that slow because I dork it up if I say pre-trade too fast yeah pretty much a smooth brain so now we get through this initial hypothesis orientation and now we get into the details of fitting a strategy

text: exact pre-trade checklist if you don't know I have to say that slow because I dork it up if I say pre-trade too fast yeah pretty much a smooth brain so now we get through this initial hypothesis orientation and now we get into the details of fitting a strategy so we're bullish in FedEx over two months what structure makes the most sense for this and what of my corresponding strategies should I lean towards then from there I need to go through my typical trade setup protocols I need to allocate to the trade I then need to design my scaling protocols I need to determine how I'm going to clearly state if my hypothesis is correct or incorrect this is a really important part of this process so for me if I am bullish FedEx and I say okay I'm going to trade it via a ratio called diagonal and I am going to use let's say there's no near-term resistance so I'm going to give it a little bit of room to the downside and say if it drops below 270 near-term resistance at least as far as I could see then I know I'm wrong and I need to get out this is creating a clear Line in the Sand on when I'm wrong the other thing is time bound because again options are time bound so if I'm trading a ratio called diagonal and I buy something that's 120 days out I already know

text: and I need to get out this is creating a clear Line in the Sand on when I'm wrong the other thing is time bound because again options are time bound so if I'm trading a ratio called diagonal and I buy something that's 120 days out I already know based on that strategy I'm going to manage it once it gets to the 60-day window on the long options so there's an inherent baked in time element as well that disproves the hypothesis cuz if this goes sideways for 60 days that's still wrong I'm wrong my hypothesis is not correct so if you don't have that baked into the strategy you should absolutely consider adding both a price and time element to this hypothesis concept and that's actually the next bullet point beautiful it's almost as if this is what I do you don't say and the last part here is kind of dovetailing off the scaling but it's preemptively thinking about how you intend to capture profits and manage your losses and for me it's going to be based on defining both of these generally before I enter the trade I'm very strict about the losses I'm a little less strict on the profits on some strategies like Trend following strategies but if it's a Varan Rous premium style strategy I'm going to be very strict on this as well because each of these individual trades really don't matter by themselves it's how they operate in the

metadata.description:

Trade Checklist Download. https://www.esinvests.com/resources

📨 Subscribe to the Outlier Insights Newsletter. https://esinvests.substack.com/
💡 Join the FREE Outlier Community Discord. https://discord.gg/hYGZUEJpve
📈 Join the Outlier Patreon for exclusive content: weekly workshops, templates, trade reviews, & more. https://www.patreon.com/erik_esinvests
ℹ️ Free Compound Interest Calculator: https://www.esinvests.com/resources
🔎Learn About Erik. https://www.esinvests.com

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose of creating a pre-trade checklist

01:00 - Importance of a Usable Checklist
   - Balancing depth and usability
   - Manual process evolving into habits

02:00 - Broad Screening
   - Ensuring product liquidity
   - Bid-ask spread and open interest as indicators

04:00 - Checking for Upcoming Announcements
   - Importance of being aware of earnings and announcements
   - Avoiding trades before significant events

06:00 - Broad Market Events
   - Using tools like Financial Juice for upcoming events
   - Impact of market events on trades

07:00 - Portfolio Needs
   - Ensuring the trade fits the portfolio
   - Avoiding unnecessary risk

08:00 - Hypothesis Generation
   - Determining the purpose of the trade
   - Developing a clear hypothesis

09:00 - Breadth of Analysis
   - Aligning technical analysis with the hypothesis
   - Ensuring the Confluence of evidence

11:00 - Fitting a Strategy
   - Choosing the right structure for the trade
   - Allocating and scaling the trade

12:00 - Defining Hypothesis Correctness
   - Establishing clear criteria for success and failure
   - Time-bound elements in options trading

14:00 - Managing Profits and Losses
   - Planning profit capture and loss management
   - Importance of predefined strategies

15:00 - Final Review and Blind Spots
   - Sanity checking the trade before execution
   - Ensuring all factors are considered

16:00 - Conclusion
   - Recap of the checklist
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and questions


▬ AFFILIATES  ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬
